title: 109_hr2728
content: The "Health Care Access and Availability Act of 2005" establishes the constitutional authority of Congress to regulate commerce. It also introduces the concept of Individual Membership Associations (IMAs) under the Public Health Service Act. The "Health Care Access and Availability Act of 2005" introduces Individual Membership Associations (IMAs) as legal entities offering health benefits coverage to members and their dependents at established rates. The "Health Care Access and Availability Act of 2005" introduces Individual Membership Associations (IMAs) as legal entities offering health benefits coverage to members and their dependents at established rates. IMAs may not discriminate in coverage offered to members, ensuring that the same coverage is available to all members within the approved service area. The Individual Membership Associations (IMAs) under the "Health Care Access and Availability Act of 2005" cannot exclude or limit coverage for any individual, must provide coverage through contracts with insurance issuers, and can offer administrative services like accounting and billing to members. The Act allows for the establishment of multiple IMAs in a geographic area without limitations on the number of IMAs operating in any area. The Individual Membership Associations (IMAs) must provide coverage through contracts with insurance issuers and can offer administrative services like accounting, billing, and enrollment information. IMAs can serve as administrative service organizations and must file compliance information with the Secretary. Health benefits coverage offered through an IMA must comply with consumer protection requirements and be underwritten by a state-regulated health insurance issuer. The benefits coverage available through an Individual Membership Association (IMA) must meet State consumer protection standards and can include coverage through a health maintenance organization, preferred provider organization, licensed provider-sponsored organization, or indemnity coverage through an insurance company. The benefits coverage available through an Individual Membership Association (IMA) can include indemnity coverage through an insurance company, coverage offered in connection with a contribution into a medical savings account or flexible spending account, coverage with a point-of-service option, or any combination of such types of coverage. Health insurance issuers offering coverage through an IMA can provide wellness bonuses for health promotion, including premium discounts or rebates for members who adhere to programs of health promotion and disease prevention. Under rules established, individuals who are members of an IMA can enroll in health benefits coverage offered by a health insurance issuer through the IMA. IMAs can set rules for enrollment consistently for all members without discrimination based on health. The contract between an IMA and a health insurance issuer ensures payment of premiums for members enrolled in health benefits coverage, without discrimination based on health status. "SEC. 2902. APPLICATION OF CERTAIN LAWS AND REQUIREMENTS." State laws related to benefit requirements and other restrictions on health benefits coverage offered through an IMA are superseded and do not apply, except for requirements necessary to implement Federal law. "SEC. 2903. ADMINISTRATION." The Secretary is authorized to issue regulations to administer the title, including the process of 'deemed file and use' for information filed. Periodic reports to Congress are required every 30 months to promote the development of IMAs for better healthcare access. Periodic reports to Congress every 30 months are required to promote the development of IMAs for better healthcare access. The Secretary may contract with private entities for producing reports on the effectiveness of the rules in promoting coverage of uninsured individuals. "SEC. 2904. DEFINITIONS." The term 'association' in health insurance coverage refers to a group that has been active for at least 5 years, formed in good faith for purposes other than insurance, does not require a specific health status for membership, and only offers coverage to members. The term 'dependent' is also defined in relation to this context. The term 'dependent' in health insurance coverage includes the spouse and children of the individual. Other key terms defined include 'health benefits coverage', 'health insurance issuer', and 'health status-related factor'. The term 'member' in health insurance refers to an individual who is a member of an individual membership association offering coverage.
